column8: Only early in the morning is the fish market busy.
column11: In Negombo I recommend visiting the harbour and the Fish or Dry Fish Market. Best organized by the hotel/hostel by bike. That's how I did it. My guide was Asiri, the manager of the Ceylon Glory Hotel in Negombo. On the way we had stopped at the Dutch Fort and various temples and churches. The early morning from 6 am is best suited for this. Then it is still relatively cool (in November) , often sunny and busy. Later it can rain and the fishmongers/fishermen have disappeared.

Visit the Negombo Fish Market to experience the authentic pulse of Sri Lankan coastal life. The air is alive with the sounds of fishmongers shouting prices as they display their predawn catch on tables. The market is wet underfoot, with rows of fresh seafood laid out without ice. Nearby, on the sand between the stalls and the ocean, workers salt-cure fish. The process involves soaking the fish in concentrated salt for a week before laying them in the sun to dry. This labor-intensive task requires daily flipping and adding salt to ensure they dry properly. The fish are then taken indoors each night, and the entire drying process can take several days depending on the weather. Tip: Don‚Äôt wear flip-flops and avoid long clothing that will get wet and fishy.

A visit to the fish market seems to be on all tourist guides list. But be warned. The smell of fish is so overpowering that some people may struggle as was the case with our group. This is one of the main places where local fishermen bring their daily catch. Miles and miles of all sorts of fish laid on the grounds for drying gives an overload to the senses. You can see lots of fresh fish being sold and also many  stalls selling fruits and vegetables by the side of the road.

column8: Do not let seemingly friendly locals give you a tour!
column11: Do not let the locals give you a tour! It‚Äôs an interesting place but very few tourists when I went so I felt quite out of place. I was approached by a persistent local seemed very friendly at first showing me the market and the ‚Äòbehind the scenes‚Äô area. Never did he mention it being a tour. Being a solo female I felt quite uncomfortable as he led me very far away from the market itself. He took me to a restaurant for a drink but I declined. He then led me behind the restaurant (no one else around) where he demanded a tip in ¬£¬£¬£. I opted to give him some rupees but once he saw what I had, he demand more and got very argumentative. I started walking away but he followed me all the way down the road. It‚Äôs left me feeling shaken.

column8: Interesting, but ruined by persistent tour sellers
column11: The market is closed on Sunday‚Äôs, drying of the fish on the beach is still on all the time but no market. We caught an uber down there from the hotel and from that point onwards we were hounded to do a tour with the locals, they approach and start talking about their methods and the fish then will offer a tour. If you decline a tour they get sour and quite rude, then when you walk to a different area you get to do it again. I would probably recommend organising a guide beforehand to avoid the endless hawking. I understand the need to try for money but it ruins the experience of going there.

We learned about the process of how the surplus fish were dried.  We also enjoyed wandering around the daily fish market at the selection and volume of fish available. And watched them preparing the fish.
Fresh fish you can get in cheap price . But the thing is you need to know how to select the good fish. Some times you might get same color but different varieties fish .

An early morning start to see a bustling workings of a local fish market. A great place to experience locals going about making a livelihood. So many interesting species of seafood. Those who know anything about fresh seafood is that fresh seafood, does not smell. The smell was not bad as some other reviewers had claimed.

column8: As if the bottom of the sea is visible!
column11: At six in the morning already at the fish market. We still a little sleepy, but the rest of those present (buyers, sellers etc) already full of their energy. What a diversity of fish! From the smallest smelt to a 100-pound tuna. And even a marlin. Impressive and definitely worth a visit. Going a little later can m, 7 o'clock is also fine.

üêüüé£ we arrived just after sunrise, the market was alive with energy. Fishermen were hauling in their fresh catches, their boats lined up along the shore, while the air was filled with the scent of the sea and the lively chatter of bargaining. The colorful variety was incredible‚Äîgiant tuna, glistening prawns, crabs, squid, and even enormous rays.i think the  best time to visit is early morning, around 6:00 amüé£üç§

A must see! Amazing to see the variety, colour and people.  Barely a smell as the seafood has been caught that day! I am Sri Lankan, so no touts tried to convince me to take a tour, but it was just so great to see such a bustling place.  Very safe, tourist friendly and an insight into how the sea is so important to Sri Lankan life. Make sure you go to the right place- as there are two other first markets close by.

a large fish market on the beach front.   If you're a fish eater then you might not like what you see here as hygenic isn't a word that they seem to know.  Thousands of fish lying out in the sun drying right besides wild dogs and birds! Watch out for would be guides who will pounce on you and offer you a 'tour' wheather you want it or not.  If you do want the tour sort out a price before you set off, otherwise you'll end up in a spritted discussion at the end. Not too far way is a much smaller fish market where you can see fresh, as in just caught, being sold.

First up yes we got hooked by the eager local who was keen to show us around, needless to say this ends up with a sit down and a negotiated price. At the end of the day we paid the ‚Äúentry fee‚Äù yes we got ripped off, but it was as good at our as you would pay an operator for and far less. It‚Äôs an extraordinary place, vast amounts of fish being brought in, processed and dried. Yes its gritty, grim and fishy but it‚Äôs real life and you can‚Äôt beat a fish market for that.
Interesting area with lots of dried fish and plenty of activity. Seems like they want to get you in then ask for money so don‚Äôt be fooled

Syrupy  local said hi and next thing he is showing us around the ' behind the scenes' fish market.  Don't be fooled - we were, and wished we were more direct at our attempts at declining . We were not that interested in the first place  but the 'guide' forced himself on  us stupid tourists and demanded money for it. He wanted double what we offered and was a supreme master guilt tripper. It was interesting to see how the fisherman work and process the fish in the sun amongst rubbish stench filth  stray animals and birds, without refrigeration. Quite confronting , yet educational ,and needless to say we didn't eat fish again in Sri Lanka. On that, you must see for yourself  , but tell the locals that you're just looking. They will be ruthless. Trust me you do NOT need a tour.

We went in to have a quick look at the fish sales area. Fish and salespeople were very interesting and colourful Unfortunately an overly friendly local guy attached himself to us and whisked us into the behind the scenes area, where fish was processed and brought to shore I wish I'd worn enclosed shoes as the ground was filthy , with rubbish , oil , fishing gear , broken bottles, fish by-products, rotting food and animal/ bird excrement etc The smell was putrid There is no refrigeration and we witnessed the fish salting and sun drying practices It dawned on us that the friendly local was obviously just in it for financial reward and became not so friendly when we didn't tip what he thought the' tour ' was worth All an all not a great experience and didn't eat seafood again , in Negombo

We first went early morning to the fish market on the beach near the cricket ground at the location on the map on trip advisor, it was very quiet just locals gutting and laying out fish to dry in the sun, none of the market stalls were open, and we were told they didn't open til 09.00,after wandering around for a while a tuk tuk driver asked us if we were looking for a fish market, and he took us a short ride to the Negombo general fish market just over the Pitopana bridge, this was much better very busy and lively with lots of stalls selling a vast variety of fish and seafood, slightly intimidating as so busy with locals buying fish and no prices on display but when we asked a vendor he was more than happy to explain what the fish were and the prices they were on sale at, we found out this market opened at 06.00 and was finished by lunchtime, this is a great market to buy fresh local fish at local prices or just look round and soak in the atmosphere.

The fish market and mainly the stages before - salting, cutting, clening, drying are simply facinating. It was our first site upon our arrival to Srilanks and it was great to see how the locals treat and organize the fishing.

Negombo‚Äôs fishing village and market raw, real, and full of life! Walking through the canals in the early morning, you can see the fishermen getting ready for the day, their boats reflecting in the still water. But the real action starts at the fish market fresh catches laid out, voices bargaining, and the smell of the ocean all around. It‚Äôs chaotic, lively, and an experience you won‚Äôt forget. If you‚Äôre in Negombo, this is a must-see! Have you been? What was your experience like?
You're exotic and smelly! but nice to do! on the other hand provide a mask because hello the smell! but it made us laugh it's the main

This is a massive market with variety of fish for sales. There are too many, shops to choose from to buy fish. One can watch the preparation of dried fish behind the main shops. It is worth an experience.

Very interesting how the fish are freshly caught and dried in the sun. The fish smell can be a bit  much for some to tolerate. Surprised that the stray dogs and birds don‚Äôt want the dead fish at all.

If in Negombo, then you need to visit the fish market! What an experience! Smelly but interesting with all the different types of fish and to see some of the unusual boats they go out in relying on the wind is good too.

First time we see such a Point of Sale in Asia. Very impressive all those fish that dry on the beach. Crows and herons by the dozens who are on the lookout as well as stray dogs. An experience not to be missed!
Authentic. Great to see once in a lifetime I recommend! Colors and variety of fish, life of fishermen, beautiful cultural discovery
This place was very interesting if a little smelly. So great to see the everyday people doing their thing. The drying fish was an experience to behold

You must have smelled the fish market. We got a little tour from a toothless old boss, who showed us all the fish species. Also walk to the beach where the fish are drying. That's at the smaller fish market that's open all day. You can shoot beautiful pictures here. Not suitable for the hardcore vegetarian who does not eat fish.

We visited this famous Fish Market, which was a bit shocking for me at first. Later I‚Äôm used to the strong smell and enjoyed this lively place. It‚Äôs interesting and it was a real local experience. Don‚Äôt miss it!

We live in Asia for 11 years so seeing this fish market and the way they dried the fishes, wasn‚Äôt that surprising to us. Yet we walk around that kind of peninsula in the different villages and fisheries, away from the brouhaha of the market it felt authentic and picturesque. We did spot species we were surprised to see.

Unfortunately, the market and the fishermen are off on Sunday (Negombo is predominantly Christian), information not noted anywhere so I leave this notice to point it out because I had planned the visit... on a Sunday! We've heard a lot of good things about it, so do it on a future trip. If you want to visit it, avoid Sunday ;)

It's worth the cost of getting up to see these fishermen coming from the sea. Afterwards the others take over, some people clean the fish, others bring them onto the mats and the last ones spread them out. Very picturesque, in its own right. To do

The market itself is interesting, but you can't help but be followed by a mysterious guide who accompanies you to the market places to tell you obvious things, and then ask you for money at the end as if it were extortion. It wasn't a surprise because when he approached we already knew where he wanted to go, it wasn't possible to refuse because he was following us and in the end we visited the market. It is not possible to do this independently
You smell it before you see it.. you wont stop being asked if you want to go there and its da best‚Ä¶ would go every day üíó
If you are passing through Negombo it is worth a visit. Lots of vendors, plenty of freshly caught fish and traders who dry the fish and then sell it.

terrific fish market for those that enjoy getting into the local spirit when travelling. Sri Lanka are huge seafood eaters, so seeing the produce market is fantastic. We went at 5.00 a.m and it was a hive of activity. Everyone is very friendly. Def an interesting experience!
To visit and photograph, Worth a visit but don't hit and run but calmly, Leaving aside the smells and perfumes, but experiencing a traditional fish market
Visited the fish market. From a distance you can get the strong smell of the fishes all layed out on mats to dry on the beach. You can see how they slog in the sun to earn..

Although we didn't get there until 8:30am (earlier is better) there were still plenty of fish to be found and lots of activity. Sharks, tuna and other large fish. Always without intestines, but usually still with head and tail. But they are often chopped off on the spot. Many stalls selling fish. The atmosphere is one that you have to experience for yourself, but it is more than worth it,
Very interesting to see how they work. The process of preparation is really meticulous . Great market also!

Showed a proper fish market to my family who enjoyed seeing all the different variety of fish! We bought a very fresh seerfish that was just delicious! Highly recommended if you are a fish/seafood amateur!
Nice, really fresh fish, we were there at 10 o'clock, it smells like fish but doesn't stink, nice bustle of people buying fish Part of the city tour that is quite fun if you like temples‚Ä¶.
Nice stop to make if you pass through Negombo. It is certainly similar to other markets seen in Asia, nothing incredible here.

I really enjoyed visiting Negombo Fish Market - it‚Äôs busy, smelly, and great for excellent photo opportunities! P.s. don‚Äôt wear flip flops like my friend did - she ended up smelling of fish guts for days!
Negombo fish market is good.. But little bit smellinp.... But we can see big fish.... Sunday is closed.... Better you can travel early morning... It's better.....

We came here as part of our guided tour around Sri Lanka, what an amazing place, I have never seen so much fish drying in the sun in one place before, you can smell the distinctive smell of the drying fish, from quite a distance. There was quite a selection of fish the day we were there and it was nice to be able to see the way they were prepared and put out to dry in the sun

This place is awesome. We got a tuk tuk from our hotel around 0515 and it was great timing. The fish market was a frenzy of activity. People were very nice and helpful, explaining the different fish and what was going on. The smell wasn‚Äôt nearly as bad as everyone says, but we were also there when the sun was still coming up. Don‚Äôt go in your nicest shoes, you will certainly get fish blood on them :)

We were led round by a guide who‚Äôs claim to fame was that he knew Rick Stein and had appeared on his programme. Quite fishy and an amazing amount of fish drying in the sun I began to wonder who actually ate them all!  There was acres of fish laid out. The walk through the fresh market just showed the huge variety for sale in all shapes and sizes. Really worth a visit and highly really recommended.

We made our guide stop to explore this Fish Market. It was very interesting but on a hot morning a tad smelly ! It was pretty busy and an amazing amount of fish were being spread out to dry on black plastic sheets. The seagulls were well feed for sure ! The market was made of of scores of little stalls with lots of variety. There was even a small fruit section, well worth a stop & look see !
Very interesting with lots of fresh and dried fish to see. Would love to be able to buy fish for my tea from there.
Enjoyed seeing the hustle and bustle of the fish market in the morning.  I was expecting a strong smell but it really wasn't that bad.  Would recommend a visit.

Well i was amazed by the huge quantities of fishes there, you can buy it either fresh or salted and dried in sun as you can see in the pictures. Its like a big market for all types of fishes, you can also buy fresh fish and go to any restaurant for cooking it. The only problem at this place is the smell so if you don‚Äôt like the smell of fishes  ‚Äò‚ÄôDON‚ÄôT GO‚Äô‚Äô

Jockin Bernad is a fisherman from Negombo since 20 years, he knows everything about the dried fish process and the market and you can find him at the Negombo fish market! For a small tip he could be your best local experience on the island. He was so sweet and he speaks really good English and German!

as the board come in their nets are  cleared of fish which are gutted on the trash strewn beach. Moving then to the market behind the beach the fish are sold, sliced, diced and taken by their customers. Fish that is not sole is dried on large mats. The smell is intense, but the folk are friendly and happy to pose for photos. A slice of the real Sri Lanka. You must go!

I visited the one near the remains of the Fort [now a prison]. Such places are always fun, full of pungent smells and fish [parts] that have seen better days. It was rather clean as such places go. The range of fish go from sharks to seer fish to prawns and any number of small fish. It provides some of the best photographic opportunities in Negombo.

We went with a tuktuk guy on a small tour which started with the fish market. We went in the afternoon, our driver mentioned that at there are two fish markets in Negombo (we went to the big fish market). You will see fish drying on the floors of the market and many local people coming to buy fish. You get offered (of course you will have to pay) a ride on a boat to take photos, we were told it takes 1 hour to get this tour done. We didn't actually go on that boat tour. I would say if you don't want to take a boat tour you can skip this.

Walked around mid morning no other tourists in site. We were shown around by an elderly fisherman who spoke great English. He hinted for a tip and we were happy to oblige as he explained and showed us working of market.. A must see...

We went to see the fish market on morning and oh boy, what a view. Long rugs full of different types of fish drying on the sun, with trash all over the place. Not even a dead cat was missing from the scenery. It was interesting to see all the different species and witness the whole procedure, but the smell combined of rotting fish particles and the wast waters just below the market was incredibly disgusting.  Great to see, take a few photos and walk away. Beware of the people approaching you, they will tell you to go with them and give you something that could be a tour of the market and then on the end when you will want to tip their time and information, they will start to ask for more. Just tell them no and walk away.

its not clean to visit ,, we went there early morning many type of fishes there to see ,, they could do something better to keep this place clean ,, we bought some prawns to cooked by our self its very cheep and fresh ..

Walked to the fish Market from outside negombo. Its all go when you get there. A few people helped me get there, escorted me. Then one I thought was being friendly took me on a tour around the market, then to churches canal, buddist temple. It was lovely, I was planning on walking it all that day myself. However, just be careful. I gave him what I thought was reasonable for an unplanned tour. He begged for me, then asked me to pay for his ride back. Just be careful and just say no, but yes super friendly x

We took a walk over and were impressed about the huge variety of fish, crabs, prawn,... We were also told how the fish is conserved and how it will be prepared for eating. It was a bit sticky...but hey. It's a fish market.
It was an interesting experience to see the fish dry on jute, a custom that has been passed down for generations. There are so many fish choices at the market. I recommend visiting

Visiting the fish market in Negombo was quite an experience.  The fish is cleaned on the beach and spread out on jute to dry in the sun.  Once dried, it is transported across the country. Our hygiene standards our not met but it is a traditional way to ensure the fish can be kept over a longer period of time.

The fish market continues a way of life that has existed for generations. Interesting to see the variety of fishing craft discharging their catch and the on-shore activities. Sellers, buyers, people gutting fish, drying racks; so many activities and then the birds trying to snatch a free feed. It's smelly, there seems to be little semblance of order but it somehow works. I didn't recognise any of the fish species on display, so many different. Good experience.

I was in pescetarian heaven! The freshest, the biggest and the saltiest bounties from the sea at such cheap prices. If only I can take them home and cook in my kitchen. The moment I opened the car door, the strong smell of salty fish hit my nose immediately. Dried fish as far as the eyes can see. Negombo fish drying area and market is where the fish are caught fresh everyday along the coast and brough to the adjacent market. Here, you can see the freshest and biggest bounties, with such huge variety I have not seen in my travels in our country. If you had access to this, who would not want to eat seafood everyday?

For something a bit smelly visit the drying fish grounds.  And then the fresh fish stands. Your Nostrils will go crazy and your eyes will take in massive colourful species of seafood.  Take the time to include fruit and vege stands too. .

Incredible. There is a place where they put the fish on the sun to dry it. Very interesting to see how they work there, cleaning and selling their products. We went there by rented car. 1 hour from Colombo.
fish everywhere. better go early morning to many types of fish as they sold very quickly.  on one side you can see the dry fishing area as well

I was in Negombo for a short stop over. I spotted that the fish market is one of attractions there. Out of curiosity, I have decided to visit to observe. It was high noon and only a few vendors were operating then. Nearby the market, fishermen were busy drying several fish. It‚Äôs an interesting site definitely but sanitary level seems to be subpar.
This Fish Market is worth to visit and spend some time to see all kind of Fish available from Sri Lankan waters. It is regretted, there is no Restaurant in the vicinity of this Market.

The Negombo Fish Markets are more than just a place that sells fish. This is where the fishing catch is unloaded, scaled, cut up and then dried out. There is fish as far as the eye can see. This whole process is messy, it smells, but is so unusual. The area of the fishing vessels stretches for a long way and it is an amazing experience to wander around. A must see in Negombo.

If you like to experience an asian fish market place this is of close proximity to the airport and is usually the first place of visit in most tour iterneries. If you have a cooking space at the hotel for accommodation you stay for the night, this fish market is ideal to buy some fresh fish for your dinner.
There was a hive of activity at the market with many locals here to sell as well as buy fresh as well as dried fish,

A great place to visit - fabulous photo opportunities!  Raw, messy and so interesting. Our camera club was met with courtesy by all the fish sellers butchering the catch.  Such tough and hard-working men but always polite, patient and funny - happy to pose for us as they worked.

If you like fish and are in the Colombo Srilanka area. Head to this fish market. Fresh fish, dried fish, drying fish, fisherman/women working. fantastic place.  Doesn't smell, a bit salty, a bit fishy but clean. Did not see any flies or other baddies. Great place for photos.

If you are interested in food this is well worth a visit. Fresh fish everywhere and not a block of ice to be seen. The market is hot, crowded and smelly, but an interesting place to see. Their hygiene practices are very different to ours in Australia., they splash the fish with water regularly. The way they display the fish produce is very interesting as well. What is amazing is the fish laying out in the sun for drying, smelly as well, but lines and lines of it. Like nothing you have seen before.

I had read about the market and wanted to see it, that's why i go there; it was a fun place. Not made for tourist attraction, but just as it is. Great experience to visit the local fish market. I like it.

Definitely eye opening and something to see but fairly disgusting at the same time. All to be expected when visiting a fish market. Seems like an obvious thing to say but anything you wear will smell when you leave. For example, trainers and flip flops will need washing afterwards.
A great visit, especially in early morning (at about 6 am), when the place is in full swing. Plenty of activity to see.

Fishing is at the heart of Negombo life, which becomes extremely obvious when you visit the bustling fish market. The freshest catch are on sale at the market, which encompasses a fruit and vegetable market and stalls selling household items.

Totally amazed by the whole process of drying fish for market or further processing.  There were crow type birds everywhere eating some of the fish but nobody seemed to care. Seemed like hard work laying the fish out on natural fiber matting

We hired a driver to take us to the fish market. It was an early morning trip around 6 am as this is when all the action happens with boats unloading their catch to be sold. There are so many different types it is amazing - well worth the early start.

We visited on a Sunday when the regular food market is in full swing but the actual fish market is closed (our guide told us Sunday is a day of rest for most fishermen). We walked past large sections of different types of fish in various "drying stages".  We saw stingray, mackerel, eel, sardines, anchovies, etc.  What amazed us is that the birds and other small animals (cats, dogs, rats) stayed away because of the salt used for drying and preserving the seafood.  An unspoken honor system is in place because no one "steals" from each other even though all the fish is left out in the open where anyone and everyone can walk by. It is a bit "grungy" but a interesting peek into the local fish drying industry.

AFTER YOU GET USED TO THE SMELL AND THE AMOUNT OF BIRDS THE MARKET IS WORTH WANDERING ROUND - PROBABLY MORE TOurists than locals - the birds dont eat the fish as its laid out to dry and is salted first - the majority of fish is small tuna

It is best to get there early in the morning and see the hustle and bustle of the market. Seeing the fish being sold and the fish drying process
Early morning when the boats have arrived is great to see. So many different fishes, large areas of fish drying, noisy, busy, a little smelly. Organised chaos but great fun for an hour.

Walked down from the fishing village / beach just north.  There you see small areas of fish being dried.  The port has fish drying on an industrial scale and photo opportunities are everywhere.  The main fish market is a covered area with large and small stalls with an interesting array of fish on offer.  We didn't get there until midday and it was still fairly busy.
We visited the market on our way out of Negombo. It's nice to see where the local fish comes from and smell the fresh fishy fish.

The fish market was one of our stops on our 2 hr Tuk Tuk guided tour around Negombo, very interesting to see literally in the raw.The initial smell can be off putting, but stick with it and have a good wander around.
spent one night in Negombo before heading to colombo and then the south and this was my first experience of a Sri Lankan fish market. Busy, smelly and bustling worth a visit.
This is also an important place to visit for tourists in Negombo.Spread over a large area with dried fish of different varieties.Stench is all pervasive.one can spend a little time here.
Never seen anything quite like this before. So many different types of fresh fish. Well worth a visit.
Travel through the sea coast,beatutiful view of nature. Local Fish market is big and nearby local foods available

It's a fish market. Nothing fancy, people chopping up fish, flies hanging around, strong smell. It's interesting to watch them work. Some people laying the fish out to dry. Others turning them over. Guy's waiting at the shore for the next boat to come in. Best part for us was watching them race up on shore in the boats. You get used to the smell quickly. We didn't get anyone pestering us for a tour which was good. Then walked along the beach back to the hotel. Not a must see but nothing in this area is. But it's worth a visit if your have free time.

I've been to a lot of fish markets around the world, but still found this one interesting given the amount of activity going on around the market, including sales, auctions, butchering, and large-scale salting and drying of fish. 30 minutes is probably plenty for a visit, even with some time for photography. Local fishmongers, fishermen and workers didn't seem annoyed that tourists were visiting or photographing on site (Sri Lankan people are generally so good natured so I'm not surprised by this!) and the scene was pretty friendly. No admission charge to enter.  Note that even if you arrive without a guide, someone may try to guide you and may ask for tips afterwards. If you want a little insight about the market, this might be worthwhile, but if you prefer to be left alone, let them know. Oh, and buy a king coconut to drink outside the market.  They're very cheap and very delicious!  (I had two in a row.) To be clear:  most things in Negombo are not "MUST SEE" attractions, and I don't believe this is a do-or-die.  But if you have some spare time in Negombo, the fish market may be worth a visit.

To walk amongst so many fish - laid out to dry or being sold for consumption, being cut up for curing or cut up for the retail buyer, being freshly landed and extracted from nets or transferred to great tubs is fascinating. I was absorbed by the opportunity to people watch - my travel companion took endless great photos here. Of course there is a smell and muck under foot- it is a working market not a museum. A must see item.

We arrived late at around 10 am and most of the activity had ebbed.  The smells of the fish and sea were prevalent, so strong that we saw some tourists retch. Walk away a little and you come across the harbor where the boats are moored, and this is a nice spot to take a few photos.

You have to come early morning! O came around 9am and think it was a bit late bust still amazing. Smell is what you would expect ... very fishy so I would advise you to take some scarf with perfume on itüòÇ Thats what I did. People are happy to pose for you (I am secret photographer and preferred to take photos when they doesn‚Äôt know about it) and all are smiling. Also some of them will offer you tour but if you don‚Äôt want to just say NO as I did. Prepare your self for lots of strange flies and dogs around, lots of different fish and hard working fisherman and woman. Ot is incredible! And then the market when they are selling their catch of the day. Some of them does have huge fish some of them lots of small ones and some of them just a few which are infront of them on the ground. Go and see! If I would be eating seafood I would stop for a while after my visit üòÇ
Great to see the locals straight off the boat into the fish market The people are so friendly, worth a 25 minute visit, you don‚Äôt need a guide it is a bit smelly and wet under foot in some places

This may not be for everyone since the stench of fresh (and dried) fish is everywhere and you may need to hold your nose.  But if you want to experience real local culture, this is a good place to start.  Nearly all the locals in the area (and certainly all the local restaurants and hotels) come here to buy fresh fish. You'll get to see locals sorting out the fish for drying, cutting up fish, selling fish etc. Fish is very much the primary source for food and income in this area, and this the primary location for the business in Negombo.

Negombo has been an important sea port and trading centre since at least Portuguese times. The Dutch took over the Portuguese and built the fort (1672) and constructed the canal linking Negombo to Puttalam in the north and Colombo in the south, with the longest canal in Sri Lanka at 120km long. It is still operational today but barely used except for mooring some small fishing boats. The location of the city of Negombo at the junction of Negombo Lagoon and the open sea makes it the perfect spot for a fishing port to harvest lobsters, crabs and prawns from the lagoon and a huge variety of fish from the ocean. There are 2 fish markets in Negombo, a small one south of the entrance to the lagoon, across the lagoon bridge, and the much larger one, Lellama (= place of bargain), to the north. Lellama is the second largest fish market in Sri Lanka and the largest auction. Open every day, except Sundays, it is a lively place from about 5am, when the larger fishing boats return from the nights fishing, until late afternoon, or until all the fish are sold. Smaller outrigger canoes deliver their catch usually later in the morning. The best of the catch, especially the much prized lobsters, is usually bought up quickly by the big hotels and restaurants by auction on the beach or by prior arrangement. Later in the day is when the locals come to buy fish from the market women for their supper. For tourists, it is an interesting place to spend about an hour, to visit at almost any time, although mid-morning may be the best time, to observe the many types of fish brought in for sale ranging from sharks, rays, Barracuda, Tuna and grouper to octopus, squid, cuttlefish, live crabs, mullet, reef fish, prawns and fingerlings and many other varieties in between. Lots of noise, colour, sizes, shapes and smells. It can get slippery underfoot so its unwise to go barefoot or even wearing sandals. The extensive beach in front of the fish market is usually covered with fish drying in the hot sun and plundered by crows and seagulls. Here you can also observe fishermen repairing and preparing their nets and boats for tomorrows fishing trip. Unfortunately you will also find a lot of plastic and other beach garbage.

We visited the Negombo fish market as part of a tour with See Lanka travels. The market with its shore-front carpeted with hessian mats coated in salt with fish drying. The fish are heavily coated in salt which deters flies and animals and turned for 2 days until dry, when they're boxed up and dispatched throughout the country. The fish caught on boats or hauled from the shore in nets, usually by families working together, can be sold fresh for a day or 2, but after that they'd be wasted, so the salting process preserves the tons of fish brought daily to the market. On the day we visited we were approached and, educated by Jokim Bernard (apologies for probably incorrect spelling) - his biggest claim to fame - showing Rick Stein around the market; but as he's been a part of this market for many years, there's not a fish or person in the market he doesn't know. So, to see tuna, swordfish, snappers,mullet, white fish, sardines and shellfish well worth a visit. When it all gets too much enjoy some fresh and refreshing coconut. Whilst in Negombo visit the prison (outside only) - the 19th century Colonial prison is in ruins replaced by a modern one, but not a place you'd ever want to be. Fish and prisons too much, then retire for a drink at Serendib, a pub and sea food restaurant whose rear courtyard opens onto the beach and sea. Finish with a boat trip on the Dutch Canal and look out for water monitor lizards and brilliantly coloured kingfishers. If you show an interest, everyone talks to you and wants, with pride, to share their knowledge and expertise.
