We visited that place right after hitting Negombo and right before getting to our hotel. Every minute I've spent here had something very peculiar feature. The fishmarket is like something from medieval times, fish and different sea creatures everywhere, every people had its own very diagnostic character, all looked like coming out from an Indiana Jones movie. There is not too much place to move and walk, because everything is very crowded, everybody is in hurry on narrow foyers and fish, fish, fish everywhere...

If you have a love for fish or fishing this is a must. I have never seen so much or such a diverse range of fish in one place in my life. And so cheap by our standards in Australia. The fishermen were only too keen to talk to us and at the same time tell their story on life as a fisherman in Sri Lanka. Forget the smell and remember you are in a fish market not a supermarket. Watch out for the local guides and remember if you listen to their story it is only polite that you offer some sort of reimbursement for their time. Negombo was a fitting place to end a memorable tour of a never to be forgotten island. Thanks THUSHARA

This was the most amazing place to visit. You have no trouble locating it - just follow your nose. Our challenge was to sell fish there, but our Tuk tuk gave us trouble and we were very late and the sun was burning into our flesh so we piked on our task preferring to just wander around and watch the locals preparing what was left of their fish for the customers. The smell wafted in from the processing of dried fish. These small fish were salted then spread out on burlap on the sand to dry. Thousands of them. Unfortunately I was not able to present my questions to the locals about the timeframe for fish to dry in a manner they could understand. Im thinking it would not take too many days because of the heat. They were waiting for the monsoon so in general I would prefer to go to Sri Lanka when it is less humid next time.
Very interesting  to wander about the market and see the various aspects from selling to drying fish on the the beach nearby.

went her to buy fish for dinner, got some great produce even though it was in the middle of the heaviest rainstorm I have experienced in Sri Lanka. The people were great, very friendly and helpful If you ever get te opportunity to have somebody cook for you in Negambo then I highly recommend you buy your protein here

Took a half day trip to Negombo town on a Saturday when the fish market was in full swing.  Very interesting (though smelly!) tour and fascinating to see how they dry the fish, turning it all by hand.  This was part of a larger trip to Negombo town which featured a train ride and travelling by tuk-tuk.  Amazing experience on both.  The drivers are reckless but good.  Almost like being on a fairground ride.  You really need to do it.  Overall the half day tour was a good experience and a good way to see real life if Sri Lanka.  Recommended.

Wow! The sheer number and variety of fish and seafood on display was awesome. A walk around the outside where fish are sun dried is quite incredible as well. As it is fish it does smell 'fishy' but is well worth the visit just to see the diversity.

Large sprawling fish market right on the beach, is cool to see all the fish being dried or fresh fish being chopped up at lightning speed! We were spotted by a guy offering "tours" we declined however he lead us around anyway, then came with us to the bus station, came onto our bus, we gave him 1000 rupees which we considered more than fair for 45mins of telling us a bit about fish, he immediately said this was not enough and that usually people give him 3000! We explained that this is more than we even earn for that time (not to mention he's basically just strolling along the beach talking about fish) but he would not leave, in the end he just sat on the bus with his hand out saying "please, please, it's not much for you" was very embarrassing and ruined what would have been a pleasant 1st morning. Just a warning either avoid him completely or make sure to settle a price at the start.
Went here as part of tour and was more interesting than i thought it would be seeing how they treat the fish and work it was interesting the tour guide was funny and thoughtful
This is a famous place among locals & tourists. Can buy fresh fish at a reasonable price.  You must show them that yo know about fish OR they will cheat you with price.
For me this was the top place to visit in Negombo. The market is vibrant and full of life, a perfect place to experience some local culture and take cool photos. well
This away from the 1km away from the city and busy from 3:30am. If you want to see fish dealing, you should visit around 4am. But  don't go on rainy days!

Busy daily fish market. See various sizes of fish. Sharks, huge tuna and all sorts of variety of fish. Wonder who eats all this tuna and how long the seas can sustain this amount of depletion on a daily basis. Not for faint hearted. About 15 minutes out of town. Can take a tuck tuck. Best time is when fishermen come in with their catches around 5-6:30 am.
Interesting to see the salted/dried and fresh fish. The fish is soaked in salt for a day and then spread out on the beach to dry out. You wouldn't need any more than 15-20mins to visit.

The first time I visited the fish market was part of a trip out from my hotel and being overcast it was not possible to see the fish drying in the sun or obtaining the fullest clothing saturated smell of fish. On such a day the fish is covered but a walk around the market to see the vast quantity of fish for sale is worthwhile. The second time I visited was a sunny day and best for deep inhalation of fish effects and day long impact of people giving you a wide berth as you approach them.

We went at 6 am with the chef from our hotel to pick out different fish to cook for our lunch. All the fish, crabs, prawns, huge tunas were glistening as they were so fresh. It was also the non-smelliest fish market I've been to, probably because everything was just caught. It's busy and fun to watch. Prices are cheap.

fish market was not so special but outside fish field & the fish boat is interesting esp for those raw method to pick the fish from net piece by piece. ha... good for reach there between 8-9am to watch the boat fly to beach & interesting work at early morning

Preface by saying you cannot compare it to fish markets in Japan - that's a whole other kettle of fish, as they say. We didn't visit other fish markets in Sri Lanka, but this was enjoyable to visit and the people were friendly. We arrived at at 6am, just before other tourists started to show up. Local fishermen unloading their haul of big tuna encouraged us to come on the boat and see up close as they worked. Another man was using a syringe-like device to sample the big fish as they were unloaded, weighed and sold, and gave us a taste, which was about as fresh as you can get without jumping in the sea and biting the fish as it swims by. We were lucky enough to get some wasabi from a Japanese fellow tourist to go with it. Delicious. For R200 we bought a hunk of raw tuna cut off a fish right in front of us, for an unusual snack for the road later. Worth 30 minutes to start your morning.

I guess it's cool if you like fish markets, never seen a fish market before or want to buy fresh fish or seafood. I don't like fish markets, I've seen several before and I didn't need any fresh fish or seafood when visiting, so I would probably not visit again as in my opinion, there are better places to go. This was part of my Sri Lanka tour, so we went there with an entire group. But yes, everything is very real and local. You get on the beach, get the real 'fish' smell, the beach is covered with mats where fish is pickled with salt in the sun, fishermen are pushing their boats on the beach to unload, local fisherman sell their fish (and some spices) on the market. Outside the market you can find a few shops that sells fresh fruits such as durian, mangosteen, ...

This is definitely not your average tourist attraction.  However, I would recommend that people do see the fish markets.  We travelled as a group and the first thing I noticed as we stepped off our bus was the smell.  It was awful - definitely fishy !!  While the smell never went away, you got used to it.  It was amazing to visit as there was so much to see.  There were the boats arriving with the catch, the fish being dried out in the sun, the gutting of the fish (not real pleasant to see, but its part of the process to get the fish onto the table) and the selling of the fish.  This place was my first insight into just how hard the people of Sri Lanka work.
It cant be more local and real than this marketing. Especially in the dry fish area is interesting to see how they handle the fish.

We managed to witness the catch of fish and the orderly manner and process of salting the fish . Was a good experience for our kids to see and fantastic photo opportunities. Definitely would recommend this.
We had the excellent opportunity to buy fresh seafood. It's cheap and lots of choices. Worth to spend.

Good overview of the local catch - gave us a good idea of what we should be ordering in the restaurants - they catch some very large fish here, and they make exceptional eating grilled.  Can take great photos here.  No need to stay long, but do go early in the day.
Wasn't sure about visiting this but so glad we did. Very interesting. Not overly smelly... bit fishy of course. Great photo opportunities.

Interesting place for tourists to see local lifestyle. We bought fresh seafood and brought it to the nearby Negombo New Resthouse Bar & Restaurant (30m southeast of Virgin Mary statue), for the restaurant chef to cook us a delicious lunch.

This is a great place to visit. Has a interesting range of different fish and at the back there beach is filled with fish getting dried. Obviously the place will smell fishy but you will get used to it.

Negombo fish market is the best fish market in sri lanka that i visited. it is the best place to see some traditional things in fishery industry. if you you go to fish market early morning you can see beauty of a crowded local market, i recommend this place to all

The site of row upon row of drying fish, different types and stages is amazing. You wonder why the local birds don't eat them whilst they are drying in the sun. The market was not busy as the main fishing fleet was in harbour for Christmas,  but this did afford us the chance to see the armada of small vessels.

We were approached by a fellow who claimed to be a chef at the hotel we were staying at.  I should have asked him straight away which hotel, but trusted him as he asked how our breakfast was, what we thought of the hotel etc.  He offered to buy us special giant prawns and calamari and he would cook them for us for dinner.  We talked a lot about cooking and spices.  Then he took 4000 rupees about $40AUD, and off he went.  We began to be suspicious as he didn't return straight away but as I was calling the hotel he came back with two plastic bags.  Fresh but rubbish calamari and medium prawns.  We started to argue but didn't want to make a scene.  Of course his story was all lies but at least the restaurant next to our hotel cooked them for us and we had a nice lunch.  We didn't get to see the fishermen on the beach but saw all the dried fish.  As for anyone thinking that the market is more interesting than Tsukiji in Tokyo, they must be joking.  And of course you won't be conned in Tokyo.  The rest of the markets are very interesting watching all the locals buy bits and pieces, and the tiny bananas are the best.

Despite initial reservations, this was one of the highlights of our trip. I don't have the strongest stomach but didn't find the small overpowering at all. Fascinating seeing all the fish coming in and how they are gutted and dried right there on the beach.
This is the best fish market I have ever seen, much more interesting than the one in Tokyo. It should be #1 to do in Negombo

I arrived there late afternoon. I heard that it is best to be there in the morning to see all the fresh catch of the day and the plethora of fishermen hauling in their catch. Equally, I think I still saw an interesting place where the locals where tending to their dried fish. Yes, dried fish as far as you can see. I saw many hard working man and woman taking care of their business. The place is bustling with people trying to sell the last of their fishes. This was a good opportunity to meet and interact with the locals, especially taking good pictures (ask permission first before clicking. normally they don't mind having someone take their picture).

The fish market in Negombo includes two parts situated near each other on opposite banks of the lagoon. The main one offers various kinds of local fish - from small ones to tuna and marlins, crabs, shripms, squids. If you're not afraid of the specific smell come early in the morning. The second part of the market is mostly for fish left to dry on the beach - you can see how it's being cut, salted and laid under the sun.

Our tour guide could not wait for us to see the fish market.  There was even a parking space available for us.  Amazing.  Walking around and seeing all the dead fish and locals pulling fish out of nets, piling fish up, selling fish and smelling fish made me not want to eat fish for awhile after the going there.   Lol. Apparently the motorcycles with the blue boxes on the back are fish delivery people. It's hard to believe that there are this many fish being caught day after day after day.
Why not? It was an interesting visit. Not a far drive from the Negombo beach either. It's not a place you would stay for hours but pleasant enough to make a quick visit

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Fish Market and to see the fish being brought in, salted and dried. I would love to have had the means to cook some of the fish on offer as there was a big array of fish, crabs, squid etc. A really good experience and I was able to capture some good photos!

I live in a hotel so I can't cook but just to see all this different fishes and shellfish is amazing. The fish lying in the sun to dry is also nice. The fishermen is working on the beach with their boats and their nets. It's a very colourful place.

As a fisherman myself, I found the fish market fascinating. You'll see a wide variety of fish from mackerels to marlins along with crabs and shellfish. Going around the market takes some 15-30 minutes. The smell can at times be a bit overwhelming though. Have a king coconut and fresh fruit at the stalls on your way out - the prices are very cheap

For the casual visitor, this is a very interesting attraction in Negombo. It is an olfactory (denoting smell) assault on the uninitiated nose. For those of us who are accustomed to buying fish in a sterile supermarket, this place comes as a surprise. It is very cultural... a blend of the Portuguese heritage and Sinhala way of life. Huge varieties of fresh fish are available, ready to be filleted or chopped. The range is from prawns and squid to mullet, red snapper and barracuda. There are surprisingly few flies and although there is water continually being splashed onto the fish as they lie on each sellers table, there is only water on the cement floors and no other waste. If you are a serious buyer, you have to bargain... Cut the price by a third then gauge your way back up. Some sellers will go down by 100 rupees per kilogram or per piece. Others will have inflated the price more and need some more stubborn negotiation. It is a friendly, cheerful market place and window into the lives and hearts of the beautiful Sri Lankan people. Don't miss the explanation on the dried fish if you're interested.

A fish market with dry fish processing area. Lots and lots of fishes. Those who are allergic to fish smell, avoid this place. Be careful while walking, because you may be walking over fishes. There is a live fish market, where you can buy fishes for cheap price. My tuk-tuk driver Nepolean bought a big packet of fish for 20 rupees(10 INR). It's a normal fish market near to sea.

You will see a lot of very small fish coming in in small boats and fishermen handling fishnets on the beach - great photo opps. I recommend going around 7 am. This is not a fish market that starts super early. When we were there in August, the sea was a bit rough and the boats only starting coming in at 8:30 am. Make sure you also visit the more industrial fish market at the lagoon for big boats and bigger catch. Go there before, as it opens earlier.

Well worth a visit to see real Negombo and the workings of the fish market.  Fish are neatly laid out on matting to dry in the sun and there are plenty of mats!  I enquired about the cost of a whole tuna... approximately ¬£5.  The place is interesting, smelly and in places dirty. Thats just the way it is.... Well worth a visit....

It was a nice place, you see the fisherman, how they dry fish.. But I was told that it's a must see and quite frankly, it's mostly fish laying on the beaches, and people selling them, if you really want to see the fisherman, I think that it's better to walk on Trincomalee's beaches.

Visited the fish market on our recent visit to Negombo,situated on the edge of the beach it is a hive of activity.Here the local fishermen land their days catch where it is all sorted and sold on to various establishments.We were shown round by an English speaking local guide who explained about the various processes and the different species of fish.On the sand working under the hot sun work some ladies who clean the calamari all by hand and salt them and then they are put out one by one to dry on the beach and then turned the next day.Even though there were birds flying about he explained that as the fish were salted the bird wouldn't eat them.Inside the covered area were stalls selling all different kinds of fish and prawns.It is well worth a visit but is a bit smelly!
Quite enjoy to bargain with seafood seller.  seafood are so fresh, attractive, cheap to buy while cook at hotel.

At first I didn't expect so much about this place when our tuk tuk driver brought us to here. The place was a bit smelly and dirty but it's very interesting to see the how the local works and how they processing the dry fish. Don't expect a beautiful beach.

We did an early morning tour of the main wholesale Fish Market. Sure it's smelly - what else would you expect?! It's interesting watching all the interaction between buyers and sellers, huge tuna being cut up and loads being carried away. The floor can be very slippery, so be careful. After breakfast we returned to see the dry fish market. Also I interesting. Pay no attention to hawkers and scammers with monkeys and Cobras.

Watch the fishermen as they take their oruvas (outrigger canoes) and sail into sea in search of fish for which Negombo is well known.  As they sweep home into the lagoons, it is a lovely sight to see.  Hold your nose and watch your slippery step as fish auctions and sales are held of the freshest catch.  The catch is not all from the open sea, but also from the lagoons.  All you sea food lovers, drool over lobsters, prawns and crabs for which Negombo is famous.  Shake yourself out of bed at the crack of dawn to watch much bigger boats return with their catches.  There‚Äôs also another fish market across the lagoon bridge.

We went fairly early in the day. Lots of fish spread out in the sun to dry, fishing boats being readied for the next trip. Lots of fish of all sizes and types being sold in the stalls. Sure, it pongs (smells), but it is after all a fish market. Well worth a look.

The fish market is worth a visit, just to see the unusual fish for sale, also on the beach next to the fish market you can see all the tuna, sardines, squid etc.. being salted and left in the sun to dry.

Fish auction in duwa island in Negombo is a must visit for those who like an early start with local experience. One could witness the non-stop arrival of fishing boats brining in there fresh catch from the Indian ocean to this market place where trading begin as early as 4a.m. in the morning. Large Tuna, Sting Ray, Shark, King fish, Cobia, Baracudda, Snapper, Mullet and other varieties of fresh catch could be bought at  bargain prices. Not forgetting the fresh Crabs, Prawns, Cuttle fish and even Lobster amongst the many fresh items here. Be cautious with your shoes & clothes because amongst the busy market it is natural if you catch an unwanted patch. An extended visit to the main fish market will also give you an experience of the local fisher folks and the action one again the market is active in the morning hours best..

I love wandering around fish markets and the one in Negombo is great fun. And it's right by the beach so you can also see fishermen emptying their nets, women laying fish to dry, and generally a lot of activity going on. In the distance, the traditional Sri Lankan boats at sea. The only downside is the unbearable heat so it's best to visit in the early morning.
It was terrible... Sooo chaotic, full of rubbish and disgusting smell... People ask you for money on every corner... Let it be! Not worth it!

This is a popular fish market in Sri Lanka. Quite famous for its Prawns. A very good selection of sea food.Like any fish market you have to bargain. If you are around the airport area you can visit buy some prawns and fry.

Early start for our tour to visit the fish market. Wear clothes that are due to be washed. This place on the main drag through the street is interesting but very touristy even at the early hours of the morning 7am ish. However, if you dare to trust someone you don't know lead you and your husband down behind the Main Street stalls then you will be amazed. Take your camera. You will find hundreds of huge sting rays , loads of sharks of all varying sizes. Some of which are caught for fin soup so you see the torsos of the shark on one stall and fins being sold separately . As keen fishing people we were amazed to see how big some of these fish are. This area is nearly all locals so you get to see the "real" market.

The spectacle of thousands of fish, spread out on tarpaulins along the beach was astonishing. They lay drying in the sun, not far from the road. Just beyond, the fisher families squatted down to gut the latest catch being unloaded from the distinctive fishing boats that were being pulled up out of the water. The entire beach was a  mass of colour and movement as far as the eye could see. Threading between the fishing nets, alive with wriggling silver, we headed towards some open-sided sheds with roofs that were only two or three minutes away. The fish market! Big fish, small fish, striped fish, swordfish... the fish couldn't be fresher as they lay, bright-eyed, on the slabs within sight of the ocean.

It was both amazing and crazy and we loved it. It was great to see all kinds of fish and how the locals sell them and cut them into pieces. The locals were were happy to pose for pictures with interesting sea creatures and it was really really great. Number 1 in Negombo.
This is a very beautiful and interesting place in Negombo where you can spend some hours just arrived in Sri Lanka or before coming back to your country.

The Negombo Fish Market is always busy with many different types of fish, including dry fish. I went with the intent to but some cuttlefish, but ended up buying other fish as well. If you dont mind filleting fish yourself and cooking then I recommend the sear fish and the mullet...... delicious curried with pumpkin!

We visited both markets on sunday. On sunday the fresh fish market is not busy but the traditional sunday market includes dryed fish and if you walk a few hundreds meter you will find the fish market.

Surprisingly, really enjoyed wandering around this fish market, particularly seeing and learning about all the drying fish on the beach. Definitely worth visiting, but get there early and don't forget a clothes peg!

A different type of fish market, all types of seafood especially dry fish which is vey popular in SriLanka. If someone approaches you and start explaining the markets to you they are acting as a guide so negotiate a price first.

We arrived about 10.30am and market was half empty. Have been to much bigger and better markets before. A local told us that not many fishermen had been out that morning as previous day was a public holiday.
What is there not to like of an Asian food market, this fish market is full of character, fish is very fresh too.  Just a short walk to a lovely beach.
fish market negombo.we can buy fresh sea foods...prawns,crabs,fish,cuttle fish,ect..more persons selling fish here.

We visited the fish market the on first day in Sri Lanka.  We have been to many fish markets.  There were many types of fish and shrimp.   Seeing the  fish drying in middle  of field was very interesting. There was one person that had a King Cobra in a sack cool to see that.  This is a place to visit if you have never seen fish market is a must.  See all the different colored boats and sailing on Indian Ocean was a beautiful site I am concerned that with no regulations on the fishing could be a problem for the area in the near future
It was a good place to visit although the weather was hot but had fun watching them and all of these amazing kinds of fishes
Visit here for an authentic fish market experience. It's amazing the volume of fish the fisherman bring in. It's an interesting in sight to the people of Negombo.

What else to say for this review? But it's just a normal fish market similar to other Asian third world countries like Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, etc. where you can buy fresh caught fish for a wholesale or retail. Best time to buy is 5am to 8am as per our Tour Guide.

A cacophony of merchants sell their fish.It is dirty but you forget that as you look at the vast quantities of sea food for sale.The beaches all around are covered with hundreds of thousands fish just drying in the sun.an interesting experience.
Large fish market which all of the locals seem to visit daily. A huge amount of fish for sale with quite the variety. Surprisingly the smell wasn't overpowering and I didn't see any flys.

Went there at 7am. It was deserted. Returned at 10am and it was crowded and bustling with activity. Understood from the hotel staff that best time to visit is 9am onwards whereby the boats come into port. The weather was burning hot at 10am and our small umbrellas were hardly enough to keep us from getting a sun burn. Bring lots of ice-cold water!

Frankly the whole place was very dirty, chaotic and the fish were being dried in a far from hygienic way. The descriptions of the local catch by the guide were interesting but the odor emanating from all the fish quite revolting (for me any way).

column7: Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands
column11: This one place were you can how fish dries in the sun, catch the fish and sell the fish. You can easily walk around and see how it works drying all kind of fish in a few days.

Great fish market - really interesting with heaps to see.....lovely setting on the waterfront.....bit smelly but heaps of big fish to see - got some great pictures - the bridge nearby makes for a great picture of the surrounding area...

Good place but dont forget to bargain. . Always remember to protect your belongings specially your purse and the mobile phones.  Also wear shorts and shoes  due to untidy ground which mixed with fish blood .

Most of the large fishing boats arrive in this market so, it can be quite interesting to watch all the process from unloading to the final sales... There are also a lot of fruits and vegs sellers arround, in a big and hectic mix !

This fish market is very impressive both in size and content. It was nice to arrive early while there were still fisherboats coming in with their catch. Fish in all sizes can be viewed while the nets Are being emptied. Very nice to walk around if you can stand the smell.

More than a tourist attraction this is an actual place where local fish trading is taking place , the fisherman bringing their daily catch to the shore and you will find some fishermen sorting out their fishing nets along the beach (if you manage to get there early mornings ). But you need to be prepared to bear the smell of fish and also the beach and the market is not that clean enough , the roofed market is for vendors and there are near by coolers for storage and transportation of fish , for many years Negombo is very famous for its this fishing industry and from here the fish will be transported to various location of the country , dried fish also very popular in the island , you will see that they have spread out some fish on the sands on mats to dry them in the sun. The stray dogs and crows are very usual sighting in the area and they have added some drama to this fishing market. Even the locals come to buy the fish from the market .the prices are determined by the bargain power of each person , due to several factors such as fuel and transportation cost the price of fish has also gone up in recent years in the country , specially fish considered as a healthy option among other meat ,the prices of fish can be high according to popular varieties of the fish , even locals find it difficult to buy some varieties such as prawns , lobsters ,crabs and cuttle fish as these fly out from the boats to restaurant and hotel owners in the area and around ( through intermediaries and their own network of purchase ) . Generally the market is good to visit and can gain some insight in to the daily routine of fishermen,local vendors and people of the Negombo area .but you need to visit this place with an open mind as this is local trading place where some of the standard and cleanliness can not be to your expectations .

Visitors to Negombo have not got many attractions to choose from, so they often visit both this fish market and the other at the bridge over the Lagoon. This market was given an overhaul not long ago with some rather unattractive shade structures under which the traders offer their wares to the public. Next to it there is an informal set up for various traders of vegetables and fruit. The beach next to the market is usually covered by fish laid out for drying. This market seems to be aimed at the public as a retail outlet rather than a wholesale market. That role is taken by the other fish market. Here there is one advantage in that there is no busy road running right through the middle of the market unlike the wholesale one. What is sad though is that the general impression is one of untidy chaos. The cleaning up after a day of trading is sporadic at best and the rubbish bins mostly broken flow over and smell before they are emptied. Fish being sold is probably ok in the morning, but then visitors come here to look not to buy fish. The other market is more interesting especially at six am when organized chaos rules. Late morning and early afternoon only the smell lingers.

It‚Äôs recommended to go early in the morning. Then you can see the most activity: people who are working hard to clean there fish, people who are mending there nets for the next trip and people who are selling there fish. On the beach you can see how they dry fish, which is not sold that day. It‚Äôs very busy, but you get a good impression of the fisherman‚Äôs life and their daily activities. And of course the smell of fish you need to accept during your visit to the market. You probably do not eat some fish anymore during you vacation after seeing the fish on the dirty ground (blood and remains everywhere!) and dogs walking among the fish. The fish market is worth a visit early in the morning. Don‚Äôt let you convinced by tuk tuk drivers to go in the afternoon, because you will not see anything except an abandoned place and empty stalls.
Almost all kinds of salty water fresh fish is available in the fish market in different colours. Shark was not tasty any

The fish market is worth a visit as you don't often get a opportunity to see something similar. Of course ist smells like fish...but here you'll see all varieties of Srilankan fish in one place being prepared (cleaned & mostly dried) for transport and further use. The place is bustling in the morning, you can just mix with the locals... and when someone will offer you an explanation of the activities it's up to you to follow his lead (and give him a donation at the end) or explore on your own.

The name is enough to explain it. The place is filled with hawkers selling fish at all prices. Its a place you can visit and finish in less than 30 mins. The good thing about it is that you can see fisherman removing fish from the net an drying it. the fish smell is quite obvious.

We got taken in the afternoon and after reading the reviews on here I didnt really want to go but actually wasnt as bad as people made it out to be! Nice to see some of the fish. I guy came up to us and started telling us what was what and we thought we were going to have to pay him 100rupees or something which we wouldnt mind but when we left he didnt ask for anything! But becareful incase this happens and they do want money! (We were going to give him some but we only had a large note from the ATM)

This is an interesting place. You get fresh seafood and you would be able to also watch how the fisherman releases the fish from the nets. Go here in the morning, but you will need to go back and take a bathe before heading out as the stench sticks to your clothes :). Check with your hotel if they can cook it for you, if you buy back some catch. It will be great as its fresh!

We took a tuk tuk from our hotel 3km away and as part of a city tour we stopped off here.  It is fascinating to see the processes and way of life that happens there on a daily basis. Hundreds of locals selling their catch and offering all kinds of fish for sale. Very busy and bustling place although smelly, unclean and very run down.   A good hour spent though and with it.
If you are around the Katunayaka airport area this is where you can get good sea food.If you have time go and see bargain and buy.

We took a tuk tuk from Lewis St (near beach) for about LKR Rs 300 (return). It was like 3 km from beach. Entrance of market is very untidy. Some people are selling fishes and other were drying the fishes in sun. Basically, this place is not well maintained and hardly 30 minutes will be enough for staying here.

Very nice market, bought excellent prawns here which were delicious later that evening, there are also fruits, veggies and spices for sale making it a one stop shop. Most intriguing is the beach area with boats coming in, the processing of fish, drying, packaging-I enjoyed the beach area more than the market,  don't miss it.

There is nothing to see or buy unless your cooking for a family and even that you will not get a good price.  Deal with the fishermen only.  It about the same as any fishmarket in the world. My favorite would be Bali or the Seattle fish market.
Its nice to experience the life of fishing flock in the early hours of the morning and the busy fish market. Make sure to go with causal cloths.
I certify that this review is based on my own experience.good place for buy fishes.this place situated in negombo

It just to see the real life of some people in sri lanka i think. You can see how they come prom the sea, how they works, bringing all the fish and preparing it for selling. There are a lot of kinds of fish to see an they are really simple, nice and friendly people. Not touristic places like this are tghe most interesting for me.

We had a Negombo tour in a tuk tuk and we found the fish market to be really interesting. Especially the dried fish. They turn by hand and if it rains they have to quickly put covers over it. The fish is set out so neatly. It's amazing the birds don't eat it but it's salty. The fresh fish market is good to see too. Real people doing what they do every day to make a living.

Great to see the variaty of fish.  Not for the feint hearted.... Smelly and the kids were a bit scared to start with, so many people. Once that inital impression has been taken in enjoy the locals showing off their catch!! They are more than willing to pose for a photo. Just be prepared to say a polite but firm no thank you to offers of help etc and they will retreat with no discussion.

We hired a guy with a tuk tuk to take us to all the key sites in Negombo, which lasted about 1.5 hours. We saw the Dutch Canal, which looked quaint and good to see it hasn't become touristy and lost its identity. However, the most fascinating was the fish market. We saw local people having arrived back with their catches in small family boats. the men prepare the fish whilst the women sell it. It was certainly an eye opener and almost medieval. Fish innards just discarded on the floor, lots of very mangy dogs looking for titbits and very poor people trying to scrape a living. Sri Lanka at its most basic.
We were late but it was still impressive to watch. Visit early in the morning. Check with hotel or locals what's the best time. All locals buy there their fresh fish. The real life!
Great for a short visit but beware the numerous guides who will befriend you and try to show you around - easy to fall for if you've just stepped off a flight and are dazed and jet lagged.

It's like stepping back in time or walking in Michael Palin's shoes! Not for the very squeamish but a really worthwhile visit. The beach is covered in swathes of drying fish, visited by crows, and the shore line is a hive of activity with busy groups of fishermen assisted by old ladies pulling in their catches and untangling fish from nets. It's busy and noisy and there are fish bits everywhere you look but totally fascinating to watch. The fish is gutted and prepared for drying in an age-old method by women working with seriously sharp tools. Inside the fish market itself is an education with fresh fish of every type on display. The big dealers barter for the best deals in a crowd of interested buyers and it's noisy, colourful, wet, a bit smelly but ultimately fascinating. Watch out when taking photos as the fisher women expected payment which we didn't have and that was awkward. The people are so nice and they get on with their work while we tourists wander about looking at them so a small payment wouldn't go amiss. Wish we'd known. You can buy whatever you fancy if you have the means to cook it and  we saw lots of people doing so. The visit  continued with a boat trip down Dutch Canal which was so lovely and natural. Very lush and exotic environment along the riverside and we saw every species ( and more) advertised on the tour from kingfishers to water lizards. We stopped at a small private landing where the owners of the house served us fresh, hot tea and  we paid for a dish of freshly roasted cashew nuts with curry leaves. Indescribably delicious combinations!

I arrived at the close of the market, so make sure that you get the timings right and see the market at its best. By the time I arrived the most of the sellers had given and most of the fish sold. It was pretty smelly!
Huge variety of fish can be seen between 8am & 9am but bigger fish are brought ashore at about 4am. A interesting insight into the local way of life

The fish market is amazing. It is a local market, where locals buy their fish. Contrary to the sterile EU regulated markets, this is the real thing: lots of stalls with heaps of fish, huge manta rays and tunas, shrimps, and any other fish imaginable. Fish smells everywhere, and closed shoes are recommended. People clean, gut, cut and dry the fish in front of you, and if you step out on the beach you will see how fish is dried, and how nets are being cleaned and repaired. If you look remotely like a tourist, a local will start touring you around, and although it is clear that this will cost you a tip, it is actually worth it. Note that there are two fish markets: the wholesale market, next to the harbor, and the retail market, closer to the fort. We suggest to first visit the wholesale market (around 8 am, when it it really busy) and then the retail market.

My fianc√©e and I made a visit to the fish market from Ranweli holiday village, we made the journey by tuk tuk, arranged by Anthony (who's restaurant is opposite the hotel entrance). Didn't take long to get there after a quick fuel stop at 1 of the filling stations, where it seems the men were having a party with music playing and a really relaxed atmosphere, was nice to see seeing as its nothing like that in the UK. Got to the fish market and was shown round by a local man named Bernard, he was on the Rick Stein show when he was in Sri Lanka. He was a really nice man with a lot of local knowledge, very friendly and answered any questions we had about the market and much more! If you visit the market ask for Bernard (the locals call him uncle). We gave him a tip at the end of it as they are all very poor people and they really do appreciate anything. We also stopped at the big market where we bought a few things. Would recommend this trip as not too long as it was a very very hot day the day we went and I got burnt so badly I blistered through my white top, so put plenty of sun screen on as you will need it.

Had a great time walking around here joking with the locals. Very friendly people we asked when we wanted to take pictures and everyone said ok. All sorts of interesting things coming out of the ocean including a 200kg manta Ray! Like other people have said it is NOT a tourist spot so don't be surprised of your feet get a bit bloody n slimy!

This fish market is located on the beach side  of negombo beach and very busy. Amazing local market to visit for sea food lover like me. It's full of fish smell and blood, need to maintain cleanliness.

I really enjoy seeing how people live and work so this was a favorite site during my 10 days in Sri Lanka.  I found the market and beach area where the fisherman brought in their catch and families worked to lay it all out on tarps to dry, fascinating!.  No one seems to mind visitors walking through the area, snapping pictures of ladies decapitating and gutting small fish (anchovies? sardines?) with amazing precision...one side a pile of heads for the birds to eat and the other something that might eventually end up for dinner later in the day!  Boats pull up onto the beach and unload their fish from nets; a photographer's dream with birds flying in for tasty treats. The market is fun to see an amazing array of fish, crabs and squid all laid out for sell and again the Sri Lankans seemed fine with lots of picture taking.  Down the way are fruit venders and crazy plastic blow up toys that you see throughout Sri Lanka.  Its a great place to spend an hour in the morning watching all the activity.  Just wonder how its possible to bring in that the huge amount of fish everyday ... are they over fishing the area?  Not for me to judge, but you can't help but wonder. Be prepared for strong smells, lots of blood and guts and fish remains...remember this isn't really a "tourist site"; its a way of life for the Sri Lankan people.
It was very interesting place the most interesting place in Negombo. It is place which you have to visit.

This was an interesting early morning trip with the kids. If you are uncomfortable with a bit of hassle from local touts or places that appear a bit dirty then this isn't the place for you. It is a proper working market for locals, not a tourist place. Having said that, we found it a fascinating place to visit and was a real window on Sri Lankan life on our first day in the country.

the freshness of different varities of fish, crabs, prawns etc. very amazing.  Sri Lankan government should upgrade this site by putting in benches/chairs for tourists, provide additional shade especially during hot months.

If you are in this area then go. There is not much to see in the hood so it is a kind of attraction. You will get a guide guy who will explain you the whole prices of preparing fish and drying in the sun. Show all varieties of fish and seafood available. Fish cutters will do their job with machetes. Ladies will invite to buy. Don't forget to tip - as most Sri Lankans like to receive ¬£‚Ç¨$¬•üí∏üí± Outside few stalls with fresh fruits and vegetables.  Oh and try fresh cashews. They're in season this time of year.

The range and standard of the fish on display has to be seen to be appreciated. The last time we visited was mid afternoon on a warm day. The meat in Beresford market looked grey and tired, in contrast the fish looked as though it had just been landed.
This certainly is one of the top attractions of Negomdo. Go early in the morning to see the fishermen at work and to walk through the market.
Nice and interesting to see. Right at the sea front. The fisher people sorting the fish and drying it in the sun.

This was a very interesting stop for us as it was very different from other fish markets we have seen.  The conditions are rough but real. There's lots of rows of fish drying, stands selling fresh fish, and boats flying up on the beach to drop their catch - sometimes with only a lot of very small fish.    Overall, a very interesting stop that only takes a short time that we covered on our way to the airport in Colombo.
The best fish market to visit in sri lanka. with the fresh catch from the sea and lagoon comes to this market.its a first hand experience, i always prefer visiting this market.

A thriving local fish market just outside of Negombo town, for about Rs 200 a tuk tuk will take you there in about 5 mins. Some of the freshly caught fish is drying on big plastic sheets on the sand under the hot Sri Lankan sunshine. A local fishman was quite happy to tell us how the process worked for a couple of hundred Rs - well worth it to be honest. The selling area of the market is a buss with local people buying and sell. When we had had enough we took a gental stroll back into Negombo town. We worth a vist, even if you have been to local fish markets before.

We visited the market after it had closed, the site is very dirty and the buildings very run down. There were loads of dogs and crows scrounging for scraps, It was our first and worst day in Sri Lanka, we wish we had remained at the northern end of the beach.
We stopped there our first morning in Sri Lanka, it was a great introduction to the local flavor.  The whole scene was facinating
Not to be missed if you're passing through Negombo. Can see everything from catching to preparation to drying to selling of seafood between the market and neighbouring beach.

Come early in the morning around 6am or earlier if possible.  This is some of the largest tuna fish we've seen since visiting Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo. We also saw some sharks and manta ray there (a bit sad as we are scuba diving fans - but then it does become a bit hypocritical to think like this)

Negombo is famous for its lagoon, canals and fishing industry. Make it a point to visit this busy fish market by the sea when visiting Sri Lanka and its for FREE. Offers tremendous sights, sound and smell : locals bargaining for the freshest variety of seafood, lines of fishes being dried on the beach, fish cleaning the traditional ways. Best time to visit in the morning to see the barrage of activities. Closed on Sunday. If you are driving, there is street parking by the market @ Rs20/car.

Great working fish market with lots of small traders with a variety of reef and open water fish caught nearby. If you can get a guide there to show you and explain the preservation of the dried fish that get distributed all across the country, then it would give you a better insight into Sri Lankan life

When you are in Negombo I advise you to visit the Fish Market. It's realy interesting and all the fish you see is fresh. The lokation is just by the sea and in the morning is the best time to go. On the beach you can see the fish that is drying. It's absolutely worth wild.

I could never have imagined such an incredible place .One of the highlights of my trip.Met a chap on the beach(a friend of Rick Stein...apparently) who gave us a guided tour and explained about the fish drying and also the wet fish. Tuna,marlin and so much more.A small donation was expected for his "English" fees but he's worth a couple of quid for his help and friendliness.
You can buy fresh fish for a very low price. Straight from the boats to you Kitchen. You can catch boats in mornings and evenings.
Worth a visit to see the local fish. Does pong a bit with so much fish but interesting enough to put up with it.

The best time to visit the market is in the morning you pick up a local and he will show you round. It is very interesting the way it works. The fish is dried in the sun and it is sent to the middle of the island to be sold.

We did this as our first attraction officials the plane, and it was kind of a bad way to get introduced to the Sri Lankan street. We came there in the afternoon when it smells really bad, and the place was quite empty. The dried fish are a very interesting sight, yet not really worth the experience and effort.

Visiting the Fish Market in Negombo was definately worth while. It's a nice way to get an insight into the everyday life of the Sri Lankan life in the town of Negombo. It's smelly and loud of course but that's all part of the fun. A particular highlight was seeing the fishermen/women bringing in the fish on the coast, shaking out the nets to retrieve all the fish.
the fishman dried lots of fishes on the beach .lots of dogs and crows looking for the fresh food around there.I didnt find many kinds of fishes at afternoon in the market  .
Our guide brought us here despite it not being on our itinerary - great to see beyond the tourist trail, although not for the weak of stomach!

We went to the fish market very early in the morning, around 7 am as the tips advised. But we found out it was too early to sea the ships. Better to go around 8 am. There you may sea the real life of fishermen.

Get here before 9am, earlier the better, walk around and take in the many sights, sounds and personalities of this very busy working fish market. From the various auctions, watching weigh in, fish filleting, small vendor stands, trucks being loaded, fish being dried in the sun, fishermen arriving, departing, tidying their nets, dried fish being packed for export, it is all happening here. Colourful and action abounds for photographers. Loved it.

This was definitely a unique experience and worth setting your alarm clock early for. I would recommend to wear waterproof shoes as it can be very wet and lots of fishy smells. If you love photography, bring your camera because this place will not disappoint. Very interesting to walk around and the locals are very friendly. Highlight of any visit to Negombo!
Get up very early to catch the best of this market, take a camera and if brave, but some fish! Your hotel will always cook it for you

The fish market most definitely is one of the largest I have seen . Very organised and the variety o fish is mind boggling. All around the market are smaller vendors and the vendors of related products.  even those are interesting to see. The fish is priced very nicely so it is not a burden on the pocket..worth a visit while in Negembo..

We were there early that day so easy to find seats. Their sea urchin is awesome!! Just $25 for a pack full of juice urchin. We also bought a bottle of wine from the bottle shop there. What a wonderful morning!!!

You get a real feel for a place if you visit their markets - and Negombo Fish Market was no exception.  We were approached by a gentleman who said he had been interviewed by Rick Stein for his Far Eastern TV Cookery Programme and he proceeded to show us around - for a ¬£5 fee!  But it was worth it, just to hear his narrative - true or not. OK, the conditions wouldn't pass UK Food Standards Agency regulations,  but this certainly didn't put us off fish served locally. .Also,  hubby being a Rotarian,  It was pleasing to see fishing boats donated by the Rotary Club of Teignmouth (UK) following the devastation caused by the 2004 Tsunami.

Went tothe Fish Market early in the morning and it was fascinating.  It was smelly and wet; however it is very colorful and gave me a good perspective of life in Sri Lanka.  Good place to visit if you are in Negombo
Amazingly shark are caughted in Negomboo and the shark's skin dryed by direct exposure to sun , then shark's skin are exported to Japan and very globally 5 star restaurant to serve Shark soup!
Can't think for the life of me why I wanted to visit this place. Really smelly (obviously) and not very clean. I have to admit some of the Fish were quite fascinating.

This is not contrived for the tourists but very much a market where the fish/seafood is landed and sold on to individuals and restaurants at very low prices. It is very loud and colourful and as you would expect very smelly but very much worth a visit and with some great photo opportunities. The traders don't make very much money so offer them a few rupees if you take their photo they do appreciate it. Good tip don't wear flip flops or sandals as it can get a bit messy underfoot.

one of the main attractions in Negombo , it starts very early morning until well passed noon. Various types of fish you can see there as well as tuna, yellow fin tuna,  shrimps, oysters, calamari's, ...etc. behind the fish market on the beach most of the time you can see the arrival of fishing boats, then they are selecting fish out of nets are favorable to see. If you want to purchase fish make sure to bargain , and you should try with few people not only one before you buy. Flore of the fish market in rainy days are bit dirty so make sure to wear something washable.
A traditional busy fish market - pretty smelly and very busy but a real experience!  You can see why the produce gets shipped all over the region!
It's better to visit it at morning, where there are many fish. There are much exotic fish and shrimps. Very low prices for it. But not good smell.

You need to go early in the morning to appreciate the market. Large numbers of tuna, sea bass and manta rays. Recommend that you wear washable shoes ( like crocs). Trucks were being loaded with whole tuna being flown to Australia

You must go an take a look at this great sight, i have never seen as many fish on the sand drying out before all kinds. Then go into the fish market and watch them haggle over fresh catch from tuna to prawns. Once you leave the market take a look at the fruit and veg they are selling that many different fruits i could not name half of them. They have 17 different types of bananas just make sure you get the red ones.

Go there Early, go around and feel the atmosphere, they let you take pictures and Holding the Fish, the beach is Right behind it, also a great sight. Have a tuk tuk driver to take you to the place where the 2.quality Fish is dryed, also worth a look!
Never saw this many fish in every imaginable form, shape and color. Off course you also get the smell that goes with it :-)
Very interesting Good foot wear as very wet underfoot, TV show being recorded the day we were visiting The amount of fish and the variety was unbalivable.
We visited the fish market about noon time, obviously, it's not a right time to be here. The place is big, but we did not see much fishes or other sea food.

Don't miss the opportunist to visit the market the color smells and noise really hits all of your senses. We arrive by boat which was great and we had a guy who works there show us around which defiantly brought the whole thing to life

I passed this market as i arrived in town en-route to a days scuba diving. I saw lots of fresh fish being offered for sale. I returned 6 hours later on the way out and was amazed at the amount of fish being dried in the blazing sun. Tons of it. The smell is unique, as is the variety and various  sizes of the fish. An impressive site but a troubling one, how long can the fish stocks take this massive depredation?
Great to see the local people selling their catch.  They salt the fish and leave them in the sun to dry.

This market was the highlight of our stay in Negombo. Only 30 min walk or a short tuk tuk ride away from the town centre, the fish market is a step into the day to day life of Sri Lankan families. We went at 9am, which was already a bit too late to see big fish, do if you can, get there even earlier.  Even at 9am though, the market was still buzzing with locals selling small catches. There were no other tourists in sight that day so we really felt like this was a off the beaten path experience! You can watch the locals get the fish out of the nets and dry it out and then take a stroll down the market along the beach to buy fruits, veggies and of course dried fish! Amazing! Highly recommended!
If you are in Negombo it is worth to see. It is located close to the harbor, prison and fortress. A lot of fish and a lot of people. Best time to visit before 09.00 clock.
Need to wake up early though to see the activities in the Fish market. One may make purchase and request the hotel cook to do something with it.

A bustling busy hive of vendors selling their fish, it's not clean, there is no refrigeration and it is packed with locals. You'll learn quite a lot by coming here and as they know Westerners aren't going to be buying their wares they'll leave you alone. We had one of the locals take us through the massive areas where the sardines are left out to dry, we watched them being taken from the nets, being cleaned and then salted. Yes other review writers it smells, what do you expect of a fish market? Our kids learned a lot about other cultures just by coming here, and we walked away without spending a single rupee.
A visit with your eyes open and your nose clamped shut. A 20 min  visit is all you can stand. you will have to pay me the next time.

Visited the fish market for a few hours. Nothing to write home about. The place smells like you would expect a fish market to smell. Does not look very clean... Crowded... Not much to see. If you do not really have to be there - you can surly skip this attraction.
brill but smelly went on the train and tuk tuk drivers were very good stopped for us to shop and everything

If you spend some days in Negombo and want see something authentic Sri Lankan, this is a MUST. The fish market is not set up for tourists but for the locals to come and buy the freshest fish so fisherman know that the tourists are not buying anything anyway - therefore you can walk and look around without being hassled. The whole experience is slightly disgusting as hygenic conditions (if there are any) cannot be compared to the Western ones, but it's interesting to find out how the fish on our plate has been treated before. Make sure you don't were your best shoes but something easy to clean!

Day after full moon & by 8am a lot was already been & gone. Was an overcast day & didn't get to see as much of the fish drying. Would be a great to see it all full of drying fish. A few good photos of what was left & great to see them getting the fish out of the nets on the beach by their boats. Definitely go early... At least 7am.

The fish market is really interesting and lively - people are everywhere, sellers and buyers, fishermen and of course - lots and lots and lots of fish! All different kinds and it's fascinating to look at them all! Be careful where you walk - I suggest wearing good shoes unless you don't mind getting fish juices all over your feet! We went in the afternoon and it was really bustling and lively - we're going to go back in the morning next time to see what the difference is. Out on the beach is an incredible sight! Drying fish lay on tarps strewn accross the sand, fishermen and boats line the shore and people and crows move between the fish and other objects! Fascinating and lively!

This is one of the must see sights in Negombo. Go to the Fish market or "Lellama" around 5.30 in the morning to see the boats coming in with their daily catch. Lellama is a photographers paradise with so many authentic shots to be taken. Once the bikes are being filled up with the fish, go towards the road & walk for about 50 - 100 M & turn back & wait for it.... You would see about 50 - 60 bikes coming out of the road at once & it's a really beautiful sight with the first rays of the Sun in the background.

It is a lively experience. You should visit early Morning. 100' s of Boats will arrive here with very very fresh fish. If you buy direct you could buy fresh fish at reasonable prices. Suggest you purchase ,cook and eat the fish on the same day.

This is real life in Negombo - we visited mid morning when it was probably slight less busy than early in the morning. We too were approached by Rick Stein's fisherman friend, Joachim - and although now he is probably a bit more of a self made tour guide than a working fisherman he guided us round the beach, where the sights, sounds and colours were really worth seeing. He was so enthusiastic about the market, explaining all the process of preparing the fish - gutting/ scaling /drying - it was interesting to see past the tin of tuna on our shelf or the lovely clean fish on Sainsbury's bed of ice! And really - the only smell was of fish - so no - it's not at all unpleasant - unless you don't actually like fish! We almost felt like we were intruding a little as he brought us through the homes of the fishing community over to the lagoon to see the fishing boats coming in and lowering their sails but actually everyone we saw seemed happy to see us and wave and say hello. Joachim was really interesting and yes, we did give him a tip for a thoroughly worthwhile and interesting "tour" - probably better than a big name company tour - well worth it and recommended!

We hired a tuk tuk from the beach early morning and payed 350 rupees to get there and back, the driver was a nice older gent by the name of Dixon, look out for him. He took us around the market acting as a sort of guide, the locals happy for you to take pictures and even letting us hold a huge one for a photo. This place is an insight to a Sri Lankans life and you feel like an intruder, though you are made to feel welcome. The fish drying on the sand and the cats trying to beg for fish make for great photographs.
Fresh fish on the market on sale. On the beach large drying of fish. A real nice place to 'must visit'. As always in Sri Lanka, no Problem in taking Pictures - People are so friendly!
Go and see the real Sri Lanka, very safe and friendly, huge barracudas and brilliant market life.....loved it.
To watch the locals negotiating at the fish market was a great expereince.  a timeless scene! Well worth it
It was an experience but couldnt spend long there. A little guide will advise you of what is going on and detail on all the fish, and how it is all working.
So very different to english fish markets..Back in time still.I liked the friendly people who explained how they fished,family businessetc.,

Get up and go there in the early morning, where you will find the most activity. It is a working place, so move around considering the people at work. My friend made a short mobilephone video, which gives a good impression:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cLjtdh2GrqI Yes, it is may appear brutal and loud, but it is a part of real life in Sri Lanka. However you will find some more peaceful views around nearby with all the boats and catamarans lying at berth.
Lovely fish market if you can stand the brutality of gutting some wonderful fish. Lots of noise with the shouting and the cutting tools. Wear some strong shoes.

What a place!!!..Vibrant & interesting with the locals constantly trading & showing the real side of life in Sri Lanka! Yes it can be smelly & hot (March being the hottest month!), but it's real,& it's not been wrapped up in pretty paper so the tourists will find it acceptable.....WELL worth a visit, & don't forget your camera!

Guided by our Tuk-Tuk driver guide, we wandered around the beach landing/preparation/drying areas and the selling stalls, marvelled at the vibrancy, and soaked up the atmosphere. It was a truly unique experience.
What an excellent experience. . All that fish for a fraction of the price we would pay in the uk. Interesting to see how they salted and dried their fish
loved the fish market, had a great tour with a little man who had worked there for years, showed us lots of different fish, and it really didnt smell as bad as i thought it was going to
Excellent hour or two looking round looking at all the different types of fish and seeing how the dried fish are simply left on the beach.  Not for the squeamish - does smell! but well worth it!

Go there if you possibly can. Really interesting even though it was closing down for the day as we arrived. Stunning quantities of fish being salted. Local people popping in to buy fish for supper. Great to see real life Sri Lanka not cosmetic tourisy displays!

Must see place in Negombo  but you have to be prepared for some shock. First of of all yu have to wake up very early at the morning , the best time to visit is between 6.15 - 7.30 , first they are selling the small fishes than the big guys are coming especially sharks. Coming later has no sense. You have to be prepared for the very strong smell, so better to take shirt which you could simply trow away after visit , or  wash out just after because after visit you would smell like a fish.  But any way very interesting experience. One more thing , I've visited also Welingama fish market and they are completely different and both are very interesting
The first thing that hits you on the face is the smell of putrid fish. A chaotic place not to be missed. Stalls are set up all over the beach and there are people everywhere!!
Place not for everybody. Strong odor did not allow me to enjoy that place, Fish and seafood are scattered all around place. Probably is better to visit in early morning

Follow the  fishing harbour till you come to a large modern building - the retail fish market (the wholesale one had finished when we visited).  Lanes around the sides, full of small stalls selling all sorts of fish, mostly unrecognisable to me.  Surprisingly few seafood apart from fish.  After the market, walk along the beach, and you will probably see smaller fishing boats being pulled ashore, and their catches being shaken out of the nets, to be dried in the sun.
never been in such a place before.. a bit smelly and dirty..but such a variety of sea products - all kinds of fish, crabs, prowns..must see!
If you visit anywhere in Negombo then this is the one.  The morning market wins hands down on hustle and bustle and is quite an insight into how the fish economy works.

After the disappointment at the marsh, I went to the Fish Market. There was lot of trading going on, from big fish to small fishes, from wholesale trading to retail trading. This place was very interesting and you would see lots type of fishes, though they are dead. There are two fish markets in Negombo, one is the bigger one which you need to visit early in the morning like 6 am as it shuts down at 10 am. The other smaller market is open most of the time.

Visiting the fish market, despite the smell, was the highlight of my day in Negombo. The fascinating sights of the local fishermen, selling, chopping and drying the fish is simply amazing. We were lucky enough to meet the famous Joachim, who has featured in a Rick Stein cookery show, and he entertained us while showing us around the market. We went after 12pm and it was the perfect time to visit because things were winding down. A must see!

To a working fish market ,most fisherman just got on with their day to day lives ,remember it is a working market therefore  it is noisy ,hot and busy. Yes we also met the tout who had worked with Rick Stein ,but we had our own guide who could give us the information we needed.
busy place, very smelly but very interesting, great guide who had done a TV programme with Rick Stein was more than happy to tell us all bout the industry

Authentic atmosphere in a real live local fish market w We visited this market in the early morning to really understand the volume of the market. Don't forget, it's a market, so the smell is bad, sanitary is not perfect and sometimes the picture itself is not lovely. But still worth a visit.

A trip to Negombo is not complete without visiting it's fish market but this is pending your ability to stand the smell and bear the sights. I will let the pictures to tell the story..... Tip; The fish market is very dirty. Lots of gross water running through the market too, so make sure to wear shoes and not sandals.

We did a trip into Negombo which included going around the fish market. Our guide Thamal from Asda Tours of Waikkal Beach told us all the fish types and how the market works. as you go in stall holder sell to the general public as you get towards the back you get wholesalers who sell to hotels resturants and the stall holders at the front then at the vey back men with large wooden tree stumps as cutting blocks cut up and process the larger fish into steaks etc. then on the beach you have the motor boats landing their catch and drying fish on large mats on the sand.
Well worth a visit.very interesting to see how how the people work turning fish every day. Bit smelly but get past that to have a look around taking in all the atmosphere

You need to visit this market early in the morning to fully appreciate it. If you leave it to late most of the large fish have already been sold. There is a wide range of fish and lots of hustle and bustle as you would expect at a fish market. Out side the market on the beach are hundreds of fish laid out in the sun to dry/salt. Our guide - Roy the Tuc Tuc driver (Can be found next to Silver's tailor shop or outside Jetwing sea) was very helpful and explained the different types of fish. He even offered to take any fish we bought back to his house for his wife to cook for our tea. That's service! If you are a bit squeamish it may be advisable to wear shoes rather than flip flops. Defiantly worth a see.
A great range of fish to see.  Within five seconds a tout approached us and gave us a tour and then demanded a tip.
There was a lot of fishes that was on the floor, so dirthy with so bad smell and many dirty dogs and crow.

My mum and I were told to visit the fish market early in the morning to see the local fisherman bringing in their catch of the day. I think it's an interesting place to go whatever time. We went around 9am and there were still plenty of varieties of fish around. Don't be put off by the smell, it isn't as bad as you think and you hardly notice it after a few minutes. We were wondering around the small market when a local fisherman named Jockim Bernard started talking to us in very good English. He explained to us that he had been the guide around the fish market for Chef Rick Stein a few years ago so we were instantly interested to find out more. He gave us his own small tour and explained all the different fish/seafood, pricing, auctioning and how to make dry fish. I would recommend trying to find him for a quick tour if you are not so clued up on fish like us. We felt he was genuine and not out to take our money (like a few other locals we had met) but to practice his English and pass on knowledge. We would both say it's worth a visit.

Most visiters to Sri Lanka that arrives in the early morning start the trip in Negombo fish market. Nembogo beach town is located about half an hour from the airport of Colombo. Many of the inhabitants are fishermen. In the early morning you can see the fish they fished at night. A must-visit? Not sure. To my mind the sights and smell are not discouraged, but are an integral part of the local lifestyle. This market was the first place we visited and after  we did not dare to eat fish during the entire trip in Sri Lanka.
Go early to see the coming boats. Not breathtaking, but interesting. Definitely, NOT a must

People reviewing have said come early to see this. We went about 11pm and it was still buzzing with life and activity. I have visited fish markets around the globe but Negombo had probably the greatest range of fish I have ever seen including quite a few that I just could not recognise. Apparently Rick Stein has visited recently and I can understand why. A snapshot of real local Sri Lanks - well worth the detour.
Its better to visit fish market  early morning like 6.30 or so its so cause one can see the landing of fish and get the real pleasure of seeing the auction

If you're in Negombo, the fish market is a unique sight to see.  There are an incredible amount of fish, both freshly caught and drying.  The market is full of fresh fish from squid and barracuda to giant tuna.  The nearby beach is full of drying fish being turned by hand. It was a very interesting experience, one where we got a lot of wonderful memories and photos. The only downside is that like other parts of Negombo, the fish market is very dirty.  There are many diseased, disheveled stray dogs lingering around.  Lots of gross water running through the market too, so make sure to wear shoes and not sandals. If you are western, you will also get approached by people asking for money for no reason other than that your skin is lighter so you must be a tourist with money.  We had lots of people staring and several approach us with their only english word being "money."  One interesting man said, "money for boom boom" while holding his small boy who was yelling "BOOM BOOM!" We were almost inclined to find out what "boom boom" was... but we didn't.

A trip to Negombo is not complete without visiting it's fish market, but only if you can stand the smell and bear the sights. You can see Cuttle fish, Prawns, Lobsters, Eels etc. etc sorted according to the size. Haggling going on around the place is worth seeing. We left the kids in the van with the windows up as they surely would have gotten sick, but my husband and I loved the hustle bustle of the market.

Visited the Fish Market in Negombo recently and wont forget in a hurry! Well worth a visit to see hustle and bustle after the mornings fishing. Every type of fish there for selling locally and also exporting. Lots of mackerel and other fish drying out on the beach which is then exported to the hill country and other areas in Sri Lanka. There were also a lot of shark!  Met a couple of fisherman in the market who had been interviewed by TV chef Rick Stein when he did his "Far Eastern Sea Food Odyssey" TV series in Sri Lanka. It's a smelly sight but well worth a visit and can get invited out by fisherman on their boats.

We mentioned to our friend Ushan we'd like to visit the normal market in Negombo, what a busy place that is selling just about everything you can think of and it seems to go on for miles. Sue finished up buying a huge amount of very pale green lace curtain at a price you'd probably pay for just a couple of metres in the UK. Being white some stallholders hike up the price, we had the benefit of Ushan and his wife Palika who said yeah or nay and ocassionally she'd get the price then we pay. Back to the main point, Ushan asked if we wanted to go into the fish market, a large building set to one side. I wasn't particularly bothered nor was Sue but as we were almost stood outside it we decided to go in. The smell hits you before the sights, if you are a person with a weak stomach, stay away. The sight inside is unbelievable, every  type of fish and sea creature you can imagine layed out in small and large quantities, all were swimming about quite happily hours before. Some traders had just one very large fish, Tuna or Searfish I think, stakes were cut off these for customers who indicated how much they wanted by pointing to a place to cut. Now for the highlight, if you've braved the smell you now need to stomach the flys, thousands of them, traders do waft the fish, the fly's depart.........for 5 seconds then land back on it or decide they'll try the next stall. After seeing it you can appreciate why it's so important to cook food properly and maintain a high standard of personal hygiene. All in all the market itself is well worth a visit, take some water with you it gets very hot and very busy. Try and brave the fish market so you can get your stripe, been there and done that. Regards, Jon.
